Award.AbstractNarration:
The Collaboration for Astronomy Signal Processing and Electronics Research (CASPER) was founded eleven years ago to develop specialized computational methods for radio astronomy. It has since become a community of hundreds of scientists and engineers worldwide and their methods have become ubiquitous throughout radio astronomy. Such numerically intensive methods require high-performance computing hardware and specially designed software. This project will support a conference that provides training and opportunities for students to make contacts with representatives from industry. Funds will offset costs of student registration, accommodation, and travel. This workshop will provide students with specialized software development experience and direct access to core developers and experienced researchers.

CASPER has a user community of about 600 scientists and engineers worldwide, and it is supported by a current ATI award (AST-1407804). CASPER supports each of the top-ranked radio astronomy initiatives of the last decadal review. This project will support the CASPER Conference scheduled for 2017 August 14-18 at the California Institute of Technology. The workshop will include morning presentations and afternoon tutorials and breakout sessions. Tutorials will cover developing software for Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) and Graphical Processing Units (GPUs) in support of radio astronomy research goals such as pulsar search and timing, searches for Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs), spectrometers, correlators, and beamformers. Students will have the opportunity to meet and interact with software developers and experienced researchers. Presentations from the conference will be made publicly available on the conference and CASPER websites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Collaboration for Astronomy Signal Processing and Electronics Research (CASPER) works toward simplifying the development of radio astronomy instrumentation by developing open source tools, libraries, hardware and software. CASPER conducts a semi-annual workshop for new and existing users to present current research and development efforts.

In addition to bringing together users to discuss existing projects, the workshop this year focused on the introducing attendees to the JASPER variant of the CASPER development pipeline. CASPER as a whole is focused on becoming more flexible and easier to adapt to existing systems, reducing the need for custom hardware, and increasing the instrumentation available for users. The JASPER flow is designed to assist in streamlining this process.

As always, in addition to the exchanging of ideas and techniques, the CASPER workshop provided hands-on tutorial participation, using hardware supplied by academic groups within CASPER, giving new users the opportunity to gain proficiency and benefit from the knowledge of more experienced users. These tutorials ranged from simple hardware interaction to examples of the more common advanced designs users seek to develop (such as wideband spectrometers and 10GbE transmission of data).

The workshop was held at the California Institute of Technology (Caltech) from 14th-18th August 2017. There were 72 registrants,  including 9 from industry groups, and 22 from overseas institutions. The training of new users is a high priority for CASPER, and the NSF funding helped support the attendance of 16 students. Most of these students contributed significantly to the conference, both by presenting and participating in tutorial sessions.
